description: From Late Latin susceptibilis, from Latin susceptus, from suscipi≈ç.

adjectives.description: susceptible (comparative more susceptible, superlative most susceptible)

entries.meaning: likely to be affected by something
examples: He was susceptible to minor ailments.

entries.meaning: (medicine) especially sensitive, particularly to a stimulus
that, when subjected to a specific operation, will yield a specific result
examples: Rational numbers are susceptible of description as quotients of two integers.
A properly prepared surface is susceptible of an enduring paint job.

The visitors were being pinned back by the end of the first half. Yet Gordon Strachan's side played with great conviction and always had a chance of springing a surprise when their opponents were so susceptible at the back.

entries.meaning: (epidemiology) A person who is vulnerable to being infected by a certain disease
